a single Doric marble triglyph (Inv. No. A 64) was uncovered in this region (Fig: 1). it comes from the corner of a building and if
following Cuvier's example
we were to attempt to restore the whole from this single part
we should infer that we were dealing with a temple of six by thirteen columns

Thus
from the foundations alone
we are entitled to believe that this was à temple with six by thirteen columns
and with a column spacing of approximately 2.76/2.80m.

A similarly selective approach to moldings is found in the ceiling beams of the Hephaisteion. Those above the flank ptera
the pronaos
and the opisthodomos employ the Doric hawksbeak
while those over the front ptera and thus the Ionic friezes are given an Ionic ovolo.
Both the Older Parthenon and the Hephaisteion show another transitional feature in its plan and use of marble only for the upper two steps of the krepidoma
rather than all three
as in the classical Parthenon.

buildings.id: Temple of Athena Soteira and Poseidon
style_evidence: The local tradition of marble architecture
introduced with the temple at Mavriki
was continued in the small temple for Athena and Poseidon at Vigla
at the frontier between Asea and Pallantion
several details of workmanship confirm the connection.
This temple continued the local tradition of external colonnades with 6 X 13 columns
which the temple at Orchomenos probably had introduced
but without the standardized axial spacings and probably also without the angle contractions _ like the Mavriki temple.
In other respects the temple shows considerable awareness of developments elsewhere: it is the only temple in the archaic Arcadian series where there is evidence for an open opisthodome
and the krepis with three steps appears here for the first time in this group.
date_evidence: The temple was built toward the end of the 6th century replacing an earlier construction only attested by architectural terracottas.

style_evidence: The recent discovery that the Hephaisteion in Athens (fig. 13) had an inner peristyle
for which there was certainly no structural reason
as in fact the introduction of the inner columns seems to have been an after-thought and the building was originally designed without them.
In the Hephaisteion the aisles exist in actual fact
although they are so narrow that it is hardly possible for them to have been appreciated as separate spaces.
In the Hephaisteion
as in those temples with engaged peristyles
the spatial effect of the main room would have differed materially from those of temples without columns at all
or with the corridor arrangement of columns
in that the particular effect of the enclosed peristyle room with at least the illusion of space beyond
would have been created.
These last presents further elaboration of the colonnaded space concept in the front and rear
where there are three rows of columns instead of two.
In the later Heraion at Ephesus and the Olympieion at Athens
which are dipteral on the sides but tripteral in front (and
in the Olympieion
in back).

this is true also in other buildings
such as the later temple at Ephesus (fig. 17).
In the Parthenon there is a simple narrow hall running transversely across the end of the building
with columns across the front and the ends partly open
the effect that of an open porch.

date_evidence: In mainland Greece
during the late sixth and earlier fifth centuries B.c. the pronaos is usually at somewhat higher level than the pteron
but rarely more than c. 0.25 m
the ceiling is high up
with the epikranitis bed approximately level with the cornice bed
so that the pronaos order is little lower than that of the pteron. This arrangement can be seen in the temples of Aphaia at Aigina and Zeus at Olympia
19 but it is most obviously embodied in the Hephaisteion at Athens and other temples by the same architect.

style_evidence: In the Parthenon on the other hand the rise from pteron to pronaos is much greater than usual
and the epikranitis top is barely higher than the cornice bed. Thus the whole order was therefore redesigned
with columns C. 0 38 m lower than those of the pteron
and the architrave and frieze height each reduced by about 0' 30 m
thus the pronaos entablature is considerably lighter than that of the pteron.
Certainly the marble ceiling over the east and west ptera of the Parthenon
which had the ceiling beams at the lower level
used all the space available at the eaves. Over the north and south ptera
however
the ceiling beams were omitted
leaving only the coffer slabs
set at the same height as those of the east and west.

style_evidence: This was a feature of some capitals in Rome and southern Gaul
but par excellence it was characteristic of the standard form of late first- and second-century Corinthian capital of north-east Gaul.

An unusual feature of the Bath capital which does not seem to appear in north-east Gaul is the trailing tendril which rises from the 'lotus-bud calyx runs along the abacus between its corners and the central rosette.
Also unusual is the egg-and-tongue moulding at the top of the abacus
which is a feature uncommon after Julio-Claudian times
and is not employed on the Silchester-type capitals
though it appears on that from the Neronian proto-palace at Fishbourne.
The Bath capital
therefore
has number of features found during the first half of the first century
but not in favour subsequently.
Although the above features point to mid first-century date

it should also be borne in mind that the stopped fluting on the lower part of the column-shaft from the Bath temple is an element more popular from the Flavian period onwards. The employment of the early first-century motifs might have been slightly old-fashioned. In view of this rather broader date
Neronian or early Flavian
may be proposed.
This is the only instance in Britain of the Ionic cornice
that is
one with a strongly-projecting corona without modillions.

the date for the former can also now be put back to the first century

style_evidence: It is toward the end of the first quarter of the 6th century that we have the first indications of the style of roof decoration which is to become the Corinthian (originally called Megarian) roof system: This is made up of palmette antefixes
a raking sima composed of an astragal or small torus molding combined with a quarter-round or torus molding and a straight fascia
lion's head spouts at the corners
and cover tiles with palmettes.
The Temple of Apollo first provides us with examples of all the forms of tiles used on the Corinthian style of roof. The roof is made up of combination tiles. The eaves tile (Pl. 6
FT 231) is decorated with a single guilloche pattern: The antefixes (Pl. 6
FA 16) have a seven-leaved palmette: It rises above tendrils which are held together by a horizontal band. The raking sima (Pl. 6
FS 101) is made up of three parts.
date_evidence: I would like to suggest a somewhat different sequence in view of the earlier date of around 570–560 B.C. now given by Robinson38 to the Temple of Apollo. I think that 560 B.C. is probably a better date for the roof. It fits the sequence better than Weinberg's later date of ca. 540 B.C.

buildings.id: The Thermal Tholos of San Calogero
style_evidence: we were immediately struck by the extraordinary structural similarities between this building and Mycenaean funerary tholoi.
It is in fact a false dome
made of superimposed courses of square blocks
laid in circles which diminish in diameter from bottom to top.
The inner faces of the blocks are perfectly finished to give an uninterrupted curving profile.
The presence on Lipari
in the Tyrrhenian
of a monument of Mycenaean architectural type going back to this is so far unique
and it is interesting to see this type of building used as the stove for a thermal bath
when in the Mycenaean world it had a funerary function.
date_evidence: trial trenches made inside the tholos and in the original drainage canal produced exclusively impasto pottery of Capo Graziano style
i.e. from the Early Bronze Age
before about 1430 BC.
This cultural horizon
therefore
cannot be later than the end of the 15th century BC.

with all of their Doric capitals
and some 66 unfluted
but faceted column drums
and one column that collapsed in line
giving the approximate height of the columns (pL. 26: 3).
A number of metope and triglyph blocks
displaying unusually elongated rectangular metopes (pL 26: 2)
as well as several examples of two varieties of cornice blocks
allow for a tentative reconstruction of the façade.
The columns are not fluted
only lightly faceted
there is no evidence that stucco may have been applied to them

and the ratio of their height to their base diameter (88 cm) is a mere 1:5.2 or at the very outside 1:6.2. The intercolumniation—a width of approximately one and two-thirds of the base diameter of the columns

or 2.4 m measured interaxially—is also irregular by canonical standards. All this must have been deliberate: the Acropolis decastyle Doric courtyard shows that the masons at Jebel Khalid could provide the full panoply of Doric detailing
if required.
The eastern façade is less well preserved
having been severely robbed
the presence there of a significant number of column drums (19 in all)
identically-sized with those of the western portico
a fragmentary Doric capital matching those on the western portico
and 15 of the foundation blocks for the stylobate are all that remains of the eastern portico.
In this eastern area
however
a great variety of moulded stonework was found
including Ionic volutes
egg-and-dart
etc.
showing free mixing of the orders in the decorative scheme.

squarish ('quadratic') in proportions
and equipped with tripartite adyton
whereas the amphiprostyle exterior
Doric in order
displays thoroughly Greek architectural decoration
although in somewhat simplified form
and thoroughly Greek architectural resolution of an aesthetic problem—to avoid a blind wall on the western side.

properties.site: Sanctuary of Artemis Amarysia at Amarynthos

morphology: U‐shaped with side wings to north and south
style_evidence: The plan of the late Classical‐early Hellenistic hall building I
which bounds the center of the sanctuary to the east
can now be defined more precisely thanks to the opening of two further excavation sectors in the southern area of the sanctuary. … The hall building was thus U‐shaped
with a side wing each to the north and to the south. … The total width of the hall was 69 m. … In addition to the total of 19 Doric columns of the façade
four further each can be added on the southern side of the north wing and on the northern side of the south wing. The roof was covered with Corinthian tiles
the termination along the façade formed by antefixes decorated with palmettes. Inside the hall there was another row of columns
of which only the foundation blocks have been preserved.
In a trench on both sides of the back wall of the northern Hall 5 (fig. 1)
the remains of a Corinthian roof were found in the fill of the southern foundation pit. From the layer beneath the foundation pit of the foundation
which unlike Stoa I is only single‐layered
came a fragment of an exceptional black‐figure column krater (600–580 BC).

with 6 x 13 columns
the overall dimensions of their geisa differ only slightly: 14.428 x 32.490 m. (original) on the Hephaisteion
and 14.110 x 31.764 m. (restored) on the Temple of Poseidon.
On the Temple of Poseidon at Sounion
the height of the frieze course is 0.829 m. Most of the frieze blocks were 1.276 m. long
with two units (MT or TM
the longest blocks were 1.787 m. long
with three units (MTM or TMT). There were no single metopes or blocks of four units. The triglyphs are 0.521 m. wide and the metopes 0.737 m. (the actual width is 0.755 m.
but 0.019 m. would have been concealed by the overlapping edge of the triglyph on the next block). Because of the larger size of the metopes and triglyphs
the use of only two lengths of blocks
and the even number of intervals on the temple (with 6 x 13 columns rather than 6 x 12 as at Rhamnous)
the system of jointing in the frieze of the Temple of Poseidon was much simpler than in the Temple of Nemesis.
On both the Temple of Poseidon and Temple of Nemesis (and also the Temple of Ares)
the geison blocks are cut to the full width of the entablature
and the backs of the blocks have a ledge which supported the ceiling beams of the peristyle.

buildings.id: Roman Temple of Évora (Temple of Diana)
date: middle of the first century CE
style_evidence: Located in Évora (Ebora) a Celtic town in inland Portugal that received its municipal charter under Vespasian
the so-called Temple of Diana
probably another local Imperial cult temple
is constructed and decorated entirely in local materials.
The column shafts with bases and the remaining members of the entablature all display strong double toruses but without square plinths and with coarse
simple Corinthian capitals.
date_evidence: Located in Évora (Ebora) a Celtic town in inland Portugal that received its municipal charter under Vespasian
the so-called Temple of Diana
probably another local Imperial cult temple
is constructed and decorated entirely in local materials.
The temple appears to have been situated inside a porticoed plaza
perhaps an extension of the old colonial forum
refurbished by the middle of the first century CE to honor the cult of the Julio-Claudian dynasty.
